title-group.article-title: Timing of Equity Offerings: Evidence from Germany

abstract.p: Analyzing the pre- and post seasoned equity offer (SEO) performance of German stocks for the period of 1985 â€” 2004, the study finds a company's choice of firm commitment versus rights offer rather than firm attributes to be responsible for post-offer return performance. Results suggest that managers opting for a rights offer, particularly one with a low rights ratio, are less likely to perceive their company stock as overvalued and are possibly more concerned with the financial well being of inside versus outside investors. A higher leverage makes it more likely for the SEO to take the form of a firm commitment. Markets react positively if a firm unexpectedly opts for the rights method. Further evidence in support of the SEOs timing hypothesis is found.
